thread.title: Farmworker claims 2 St. Paul businesses wrongly exposed seasonal laborers to pesticides
thread.title_full: Farmworker claims 2 St. Paul businesses wrongly exposed seasonal laborers to pesticides | OregonLive.com

author: Bryan Denson | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Farmworker claims 2 St. Paul businesses wrongly exposed seasonal laborers to pesticides
text:
A seasonal farmworker accuses two agricultural businesses in Marion County of exposing him to pesticides without protection and intermittently failing to provide him and other laborers with clean water and sanitary bathrooms.
Hector Rojas, 57, alleges in a lawsuit filed in Eugene's U.S. District Court that he was wrongfully fired after confronting managers and a supervisor about conditions at McKay Farms and Advanced Ornamentals .
Rojas seeks unspecified damages for what his lawsuit describes as wrongful discharge, breaches of Oregon employment law and violations of the federal Migrant & Seasonal Worker Protection Act .
No one at McKay Farms returned phone calls left Tuesday by The Oregonian/OregonLive. A woman who answered the phone at Advanced Ornamentals hung up on a reporter seeking comment.
The businesses, which share an address on French Prairie Road Northeast near St. Paul, together produce melons, vegetables, trees, flowering plants, bark dust, soils, sod compost, rock and gravel, according to their websites.
The lawsuit claims that Rojas went to work for the companies on Aug. 18, 2014, and was fired less than two months later.
In that time, Rojas alleges, the companies failed to post a required notice of agricultural workers' rights; limited workers' access to toilets, sanitary bathrooms and clean water; and failed to provide protective gear or adequate information about pesticides being sprayed nearby.
"We just unfortunately see this kind of exploitation and abuse of working conditions to be really common in agriculture and other low-wage work in the state of Oregon," said attorney Bonnie Allen-Sailer with the Northwest Workers' Justice Project , which brought the suit on Saturday on behalf of Rojas. "So this is a small part in our fight to improve that."
